Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JJO I had a mapping biopsy, but it was done to determine if I had PCa in the first place. It would seem to me, however, that in the grand scheme of things, the benefits of getting all the necessary data to make an informed decision about whether to treat, if and so, what treatment to use, would easily outweigh the speculative risk of some cancer cells spreading. Interesting that they did a 3DMB in the first place. I think you're right, the more info is worth it if necessary.

Posts.Title: 3D Mapping Biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Jazz, the issue of "needle tract spreading" or "needle tracking" is often discussed on prostate cancer forums. Studies have shown that it is possible, but extremely rare, like one in thousands. The general consensus is that if you need a biopsy, you should not let that remote possibility stop you. OK, good to know. Thanks!

Posts.Title: 3D Mapping Biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi all, I was wondering if anyone had had a 3D mapping biopsy to help in selecting the best treatment for their PCa. I had an MRI which showed a bulge toward the prostate capsule and the doc I'm seeing has recommended that I get one. Since I am not considering surgery, it seems like the best way to get the clearest picture of what I'm dealing with. But I am concerned about possible leakage of cancer cells from the needles.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH I'm sure there are some among us here that can adequately answer your question. Since you are not considering surgery, are you thinking of radiation? Both are equally curative, although you should probably consult with top experts in both treatment types just to cover all the bases. Yes, I'm thinking of radiation, maybe cryo. Surgery scares me and I've had a lot of surgery already. I'm still talking to various doctors. From what they saw on the MRI and the 3+4 Gleason score, I don't think I will be doing the AS. Thanks!

Posts.Title: 3D Mapping Biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Jazz, If you are looking at radiation options, the three types that have the best study results are SBRT, proton beam, and HDR brachytherapy. Cryo has the downside of near-total ED. I had discussed this with the leader of a cryo clinical trial at Johns Hopkins. Not for me, please. Regarding the three forms of radiation that I suggested, please try to consult with a specialist in each one, and not let others describe those they don't perform. There is often a surprising knowledge gap about other specialties. OK, thanks. I made an appt. today to see a brachytherapy doc. I have previously spoken with a EBRT doc but may revisit with him after I talk to the brachytherapy doc.

It appears that the non-recurrence rates may not be as good as other treatments, but most of the studies I have found are not that recent and enrollment is less than other studies. I was directed to this study (abstract only): https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29126844 I've also found this site useful in comparing different treatment: https://prostatecancerfree.org

Posts.Title: Any feedback on Cryotherapy as a primary treatment?

Posts.Content: Hello all, I'm interested in any feedback on Cryotherapy, either focal or total, as a primary treatment for PCa. I know it is not highly accepted in the medical community in general as a primary treatment, but was wondering if anybody might have first hand experience or knowledge of someone else who has elected to have this treatment. Thanks

Posts.Title: Any feedback on Cryotherapy as a primary treatment?

Posts.Content: Hi Chuck, Thank you for the warm welcome. I have been researching all treatment options and Cryo interests me. It seems that Cryo is one of the new kids on the block (along with HIFU) that does not yet have a lot of studies. And the studies that are out there are limited in duration. Consequently, it isn't surprising that it is not an Accepted Treatment. There is a 2017 study out by Dr. Al Barqawi, el al, who just happens to be one of my doctors here in Denver, that is very encouraging regarding low side effects of treatment, which of course is a major concern, along with cure rates. But it too is limited in duration and total patients enrolled (393 men from 2007 - 20015). It is interesting to me that Cryo is accepted as the salvage treatment for failed radiation therapy, whereby additional radiation may not be possible and surgery would be risky. If the cure rates would be comparable to other treatments and both short term and long term side effects reduced, then it may prove to be additional option for primary treatment. I am scheduled for a prostate MRI at the end of next week and I have also had my biopsy slides sent out for an Oncotype DX test. Hopefully, all of this information will give me a better idea of where I stand and what options are best available to me. Until then the research and reading goes on...and on....and on....and on................. All the best, John

Posts.Content: OK, I see now. Thanks for the explanation and the links. At first I could understand toxicity in regards to radiation and didn't understand how that applied to cryo. But the v.3 2009 link shows that it is the side effects that we always talk about. Once again, the problem with cryo is to find the most up to date studies, plus as I understand it they now have 4th generation equipment and techniques available. Thanks again to everybody. This is a great site!

Posts.Title: Any feedback on Cryotherapy as a primary treatment?

Posts.Content: Hello All, There is currently an ongoing trial on this which would be of great interest to me if there were any results yet, which unfortunately there aren't. My RO is saying there might be some benefit to me to do a 4 month course of ADT in conjunction with SBRT since my genomic score came back showing an unfavorable intermediate risk. He said it is my decision. I've read about all the bad side effects ADT causes, some pretty serious including possible liver problems. Of course, I don't even know if my insurance company would even pay for ADT given my biopsy results and of they did, if that would affect whether they would then approve SBRT. I was wondering of anybody with intermediate Ca had to make this choice and how they tolerated the ADT. Thanks

Posts.Title: ADT and SBRT Versus SBRT for Intermediate Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ezhoe First off I'm a total rookie on this, but if your stats are correct you are ..not. unfavorable intermediate risk.. the standard of care for UF risk includes at least short term ADT. if I plug in my stats to a risk program it shows 20% + chance of Lymph node and SV invasion, plus small chance of distant METS. so Adt would be strongly suggested. In your case you may not need ADT.. They are giving me Tomotherapy because of my history of BPH and several years of urinary issues. I got 6mo eligard shot 2 months ago and only 4 treatments of Tomo so far.. SE's are not horrible .. mostly night sweats good luck.. Ed Hey Ed, well the UI comes from the OncotypeDX report. Seems borderline to me, but it's there. Hence the discussion of ADT. I think it could be argued either way, it would have been better for the OCDX report to have come back as just FI. But the consideration is to get the best possible outcome and the short course of ADT is an option. Good luck to you and thanks for the info!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Here is a recent article in which the writer is of the opinion that ADT does not make a difference with SBRT in treating unfavorable intermediate risk patients. He has written other pieces in the past with the same opinion from different studies. Perhaps you should google "allen edel adt sbrt" to find some of his other articles. https://prostatecancerinfolink.net/2...-low-toxicity/ Great article! Thanks, I hadn't seen it. I'll certainly search some more for his articles.

Posts.Title: ADT and SBRT Versus SBRT for Intermediate Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi Jazzman! Coincidentally this summary just arrived in my email box. Document dated Wed, Oct 24! Titled: "SBRT has excellent outcomes for intermediate risk patients" https://pcnrv.blogspot.com/2018/10/s...mp%3B+Views%29 I have a friend/neighbor who was treated by a "Guru" in NYC with SBRT about 6 years ago. His recovery was fairly rough but is now doing fine. He did not have ADT. Talk to the URO RO about the recovery process and realistic expectations. I would also ask to speak to 3 patients about their experience. (This is standard regardless of one's treatment decision) Good luck! MF Very encouraging indeed. Thanks!
